text: I disagree with yr description of Obs editorial line, but as i said before: if a paper's *own editorial line* enrages readers, I get that. But this is about a guest op ed. The day readers can't even bear a paper to publish those is alarming.
author: gabyhinsliff

text: Broadsheet comment pages are *meant* to cover a vast range of views (as do Obs readers btw, perhaps more so than Guardian ones) & news will sometimes annoy you. Crucially tho job of reporters now is scrutinising  PM against what she’s just said
author: gabyhinsliff

text: ..eg coming out for Iraq war is one thing & understandable whether or not you agree. Objecting to it publishing an op ed by the PM I genuinely can’t fathom. We have always run pieces by all party leaders. It’s what papers do.
author: gabyhinsliff

text: I began reading the Obs so long ago I can’t even remember,but probably 35 years. I worked for it for nine years. I bloody love the Observer, know a fair bit about its (v politically diverse) readers. Objecting to a paper’s editorial stance..
author: gabyhinsliff

text: Why? A paper’s own editorial expresses its own view. Its comment pages are for a range of opinions, some of which it agrees with & some it doesn’t. All party leaders should be free to write for all papers & readers will judge accordingly.
author: gabyhinsliff

text: My guess is that’s going to be the near-universal reaction. Which is healthy; newspapers report, readers exercise judgment.
author: gabyhinsliff

text: I think what you don’t get is that I’m defending newspapers’ right to do news, some of which you won’t like. Observer readers are more than bright enough to make their own minds up about the legitimacy of any pitch any politician makes
author: gabyhinsliff

text: You pay for everything the Observer does, which will include sometimes stories you don’t like/aren’t interested in but that other Observer readers do. Just as sometimes they put up with bits they don’t like but which you do.
author: gabyhinsliff

text: All papers, the Obs included, spend a vast amount of time analysing Tory policies. A politician can call themselves whatever they want; but if they don’t then live up to that description, they can be judged accordingly
author: gabyhinsliff

text: Why on earth shouldn’t all politicians write for all news papers & let their readers decide?
author: gabyhinsliff

text: I’ve already said that I doubt it’ll work, because it lacks the policies (eg a total rethink on welfare) that might make non-Tories reconsider. But that’s a separate issue from ‘how very dare a paper report it’
